review_title: Leave after a year, not a real engineering job
pros: Easy to get the job - phone interview only. Didn't come in for an in person interview. Use this job as easy and steady income to apply for better positions.
cons: Underpaid salary, more than the minimum of any entry-level engineering positions. No advancement, no raises, no bonuses. You have no voice against the production team as they blame engineers for low numbers instead of trying to come up with a solution. You have to come in during Saturdays or help set up the production line. You can get sent to night shift on short notice and you will never be sent to day shift again. You are mostly doing technician work with basic troubleshooting. Management was horrible and based on nepotism. Basically, the people that move up are those that speak Mandarin.

pros: From Nov 2018 - January 2019 at the Elk Grove, CA location, there was a good work environment. Coworkers were fun and likeable. Management did well. Pay was decent for the work done.
cons: They carried out a useless policy in a silly and ineffective manner. We originally had a test to see if we can use screws within a certain time before getting hired. When I got rehired, they didn't do this test beforehand. We got this on our first work day with no notice. There wasn't even a procedure this time - just a fellow coworker seeing us unscrew and screw on ONE screw, no timer, no notes. Just marked something on his paper and separated us by people who passed and failed according to whatever criteria he used. It was never mentioned and we all did a good job with it, but according to this guy we weren't doing screwing to his liking and that gave the company grounds to end our assignment. How it was carried out was rather poorly. 10 minutes into our second work day, we were told we needed to leave and security escorted us out. It was abrupt and no warning was given. I know I can use screws because that was my station when I was originally hired. Because of this decision, we aren't allowed to get rehired there.

pros: Free GYM, nice restaurant, beautiful lobby, and 7+ holiday bonus per year more than others.
cons: Some people are really good, but most of employees very need to be improved their expertise. For example, I met a system PM with 19 years work experience, but even so she still has no idea about R&D's job, like development process. Another example, some R&D do not have enough professional expertise they should know in their position, like thermal engineer do not know Thermodynamics or Heat transfer, etc. Only public lobby is decorated, our working place is rough. You can't apply overtime pay but you have to work overtime. A cheap company.

pros: 1. you can learn a lot if put your mind into it leading the project/working with the RD teams. 2. a real challenge since you have to work with a very complex organization with divided RD teams which requires a lot of coordination/management
cons: some of the middle level supervisors are really garbage, they can't work independently as a sole PM in any single NPI project because they know they can't do it right, instead, they have to have a subordinate to "co-work" with to be able to be a hands-on PM. Pathetic! And more pathetic is their supervisors allow these useless middle-level supervisors to keep in this state, which is really a waste of the company's money and not fair to those front-end PMs fighting for a success of a NPI project.

pros: Get your foot in the tech field
cons: Everything. I've never been to a job where they treat everyone like a prisoner. I have to walk in thru a Metal detector, then when you go on break or to use the restroom. You walk through another metal detector. You only get 15 minute break and 30min lunch. If you happen to step on a tiny metal screw on your shoe and you beep on the way out. You just lost 10min of your break time cause they will wand you and you won't get that time back. I think that is illegal what they are doing. Getting wand should not lose your break time. They watching you like a hawk. They say no hats are allow, but I see people wearing hats.
